Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Azure Search] Figure out automatic secret rotation for Azure Search Service" (#7337) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
The Azure Search web app can live indefinitely and secrets are cached for process lifetime.

How do we get new secrets picked up without redeployment?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Azure Search] Search should be case-insensitive" (#7481) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
/cc @shishirx34 

In both Azure Search and old Lucene search there is clearly some search queries that work better if you give the search term "hints" by matching the original casing of, say, a package ID.

For example, [`sqlsugar`](https://www.nuget.org/packages?q=sqlsugar) vs. [`SqlSugar`](https://www.nuget.org/packages?q=SqlSugar) yield different results. This is non-intuitive. My theory is that the general expectation of users is that search is a case-insensitive thing and adding proper camel/pascal case to a search term has no effect. From the user's perspective this is just extra work to get the casing right when search should just figure it out for them

We should listen to customer feedback after Azure Search goes live and triage this pain point against others.

We can also improve the UX by adding simple help text saying "original casing helps search relevancy" or even a "did you mean" feature to rectify the casing.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Add message to self service delete." (#7480) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Small PR to improve the self service account delete scenario.
Adds a message to the post redirect to indicate that an action was taken.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Remove noisy error log from ContentService" (#7477) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Only log an error if none of the extensions work.
Also removed an unused method and associated test code.
Address https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/2497

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Icons] catalog2dnx IconUrl ingestion" (#7061) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened issue "[Icons] Job to ingest IconUrls" (#7479) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Replaces #7061.

Need a job that will run parallel to catalog2dnx and copy external icons into the flat container (so we have no chance of affecting the package publishing).

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Icons] Gallery should warn when IconUrl is used" (#7478) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
We need to get a warning when package specifies `iconUrl` but no `icon`.

> <iconUrl> element will be deprecated, please consider switching to specifying the icon in the package. [Learn more](https://aka.ms/deprecateIconUrl).

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Icons] Figure out how to get hosted icon URL everywhere" (#7069) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Reflow all existing packages with icon URLs.
Update Gallery DB with the flag indicating the presence of the icon in flat container.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Remove noisy error logs from ContentService" (#7477) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Only log an error if none of the extensions work.
Also removed an unused method and associated test code.
Address https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/2497

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Re-opening "installed nugets" screen should use cached results" (#8492) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Environment

 * Visual Studio 16.2.3+29215.179
 * Solution https://github.com/Fody/FodyAddinSamples/
 * Windows 10
 * Nuget 5.2.0

Repro Steps

 * A build has happened so all packages have been restored
 * The "installed nugets" screen has been previously opened. so all requests and responses for nuget info have occurred
 * review the nugets by scrolling down
 * No changes have happened to any csproj
 * Re-open the "installed nugets" screen
 * review the nugets by scrolling down

Expected result: 

 * one web request per nuget to check if an new version has been released since the last time the 
 * since there are no new updates every one of those results should be a 304 no modified with no data

Actual results:

~200 web requests. none of them 304 no modified

```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NPM Add Package failing (unable to get local issuer certificate)" (#8491) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

Nuget Package Manager Version 1.1.6
VS Code (with latest updates applied)

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version:
Do not recall when this didn't work, but been working on a project for awhile with no new Nuget packages added.

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

Ctrl Shift P, Add Nuget Package, type in anything for the search, enter, and I get the following error.

> request to https://api-v2v3search-0.nuget.org/autocomplete?q=Dapper&prerelease=true&take=100 failed, reason: unable to get local issuer certificate

I've tried reinstalling the Nuget Package Manager.  Visual Studio still works fine from 'Manage Nuget Packages for Solution/Project'.  This is only happening in VS Code at this point.

I've tried changing turning off/on Proxy Strict SSL in VS Code settings file, same error.

Any suggestions on what could be causing this or what to check on my system?  Thanks!

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue " [Test Failure] The ‘Update’ button is disabled in ‘Installed’ tab on PM UI" (#8483) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet Version: Dev\5.3.0.6182
VS Version: VS Master\29221.49
OS Version: Windows-10-Enterprise-19H1-04-01-2019

## Installation steps: 
1. Install VS from: [https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=2963681&view=results](url)
2. Install NuGet Client: [\\\ddfiles\Drops\NuGet\Drops\CI\NuGet.Client\Dev\5.3.0.6182\artifacts\VS15\NuGet.Tools.vsix](url)

## Repro steps: 

1. Create a C# Console App (.NET Framework) Project.
2. Open PM UI and install ‘NUnit’ with an older version.
3. Navigate to ‘Installed’ tab and observe the package ‘Nunit’.

## Expected:
The ‘Update’ button is available and the ‘available update’ tag is shown under package icon as below. 
![expected](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632775/63503916-028ed680-c503-11e9-8f7b-fd8dda476468.png)

## Actual:
The ‘Update’ button is disabled and the ‘available update’ tag was missed as below.
![actual](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632775/63504212-a082a100-c503-11e9-85b0-c6736d098eab.png)

## Notes: 
1. The issue **not** repro on VS Master\29221.49 with implicit NuGet Client Dev\5.3.0.6167.
2. The issue repro on solution PM UI.
3. The issue repro on other projects.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Add test for NuGet/NuGet.Client#3024 change" (#8490) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: NuGet/NuGet.Client#3024 code change added quickly to meet shipping schedule. Need to add test.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Bad or mistaken issue filed." (#8489) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: Bad or mistaken issue filed.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "ig" (#8489) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Please read the following information before posting the issue.

## Before posting the issue...

* If you're having trouble with the NuGet.org Website, please post in [NuGetGallery issues](http://github.com/nuget/nugetgallery/issues)
* If you're having trouble with the NuGet client tools (the Visual Studio extension, NuGet.exe command line tool, etc.), you are in the right place.

Remove the content above here and fill out details below.

## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe):

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx):

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate):

VS version (if appropriate):

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)):

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version:

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1.

2.

...

## Other suggested things

### Verbose Logs

Please include verbose logs (NuGet.exe <COMMAND> -verbosity detailed | dotnet.exe <COMMAND> --verbosity diag | etc...)

### Sample Project

Very helpful if you can zip a project and paste into this issue!

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Embedded icon support in NuGet" (#8488) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Includes embedded icons support in the following NuGet clients:

- nuget.exe
- dotnet.exe
- MSBuild tasks.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Embedded icon support in NuGet" (#8488) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Includes embedded icons support in the following NuGet clients:

- nuget.exe
- dotnet.exe
- MSBuild tasks.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Support for `<PackageIcon/>` in .*proj files" (#7992) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
`nuget.exe` and `dotnet.exe` should be able to recognize and process `<PackageIcon/>` property in new-style csproj projects.

The main issue is: https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/352

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "VS:  ngen priority should be 3 not 2" (#8487) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: I've been told that NuGet ngen priority should be 3 not 2.

Events.RelatedBody:

We have directed your feedback to the appropriate engineering team for further evaluation. The team will review the feedback and notify you about the next steps.

 _These are the original issue solutions:_ (no solutions)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "VS:  ngen priority should be 3 not 2" (#8487) at NuGet/Home

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Using OData to query NuGet.org repository is being deprecated" (#37) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
We introduced `V3 APIs` in early 2016. We have made continuous investments to make it more reliable, performant and secure. Going forward, we plan to bring all new features and improvements only to the newer `V3 APIs`. As part of this strategy, we are deprecating the usage of `OData` queries. Subsequently, we plan to **disable the `OData` queries starting Feb 5th, 2020**.

**Call to Action: Transition to V3 APIs**

Here are some resources to help you with the migration:
* [NuGet Server `V3 APIs` reference](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/switching-from-wcf-odata-to-web-api/)
* [Guide to transition from NuGet `V2 API` to `V3 API`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/guides/api/query-for-all-published-packages). 
* [Blog post: Switching from WCF OData to Web API](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/switching-from-wcf-odata-to-web-api/)

If you need further help in moving your use case to `V3 APIs`, do reach out to us at [support@nuget.org](mailto:support@nuget.org).

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Replace reference to codeplex issue numer 3072" (#36) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
This is copy of codeplex issue number 3072 as it is referenced inside code. I should do a PR shortly to address this one.

The place where it is referenced is RuntimeHelper.cs:150


---

We're hitting an issue with Microsoft.Bcl package where NuGet is adding a binding redirect for a binary that is considered part of the framework, this causes the application to crash because the binding redirect refers to assembly version that is not available at runtime.

@Repro:

1. Create a new Console Application targeting 4.5
2. Create a new Portable Library targeting .NET Framework 4.5, Silverlight 4, Windows Phone 7.5 and .NET for Windows Store apps
3. Add a reference to the portable library from the Console Application
4. Install the Microsoft.Bcl package (1.0.16-rc) to both projects

@Expected: No binding redirect for System.Runtime in the .NET Framework 4.5 project because a ___later version___ is part of the target framework (see C:\Program Files (x86)\Reference Assemblies\Microsoft\Framework\.NETFramework\v4.5\RedistList\FrameworkList.xml)
@Actual: Binding redirect

<dependentAssembly>
<assemblyIdentity name="System.Runtime" publicKeyToken="b03f5f7f11d50a3a" culture="neutral" />
<bindingRedirect oldVersion="0.0.0.0-1.5.11.0" newVersion="1.5.11.0" />
</dependentAssembly>


You can use the IVsFrameworkMultiTargeting to determine if a given assembly version is available as part of a given target framework.
Make sure when you fix this, that you only skip the binding redirect if ___a later or same version___ is available in the framework.  
2013-02-22

---

We'll do this in 2.4 release.  
2013-02-26

---

Is IVsFrameworkMultiTargeting.IsReferenceableInTargetFx the method I need to call? What should I pass to pwszAssemblySpec?  
2013-06-08

---

It's the full name of the assembly (mscorlib, Version=[version], PublicKeyToken=[token], Culture=[culture]). It can either contain all the information (key, version, etc), or just the simple name ("mscorlib")  
2013-06-10

---

So look like I can only check for the same version of the target framework. Can't check for a later version using this method, because I don't know what future versions will be.  
2013-06-12

---

That's fine. That's exactly the behavior we want. For example, System.Runtime didn't ship in 4.0, but did in 4.5. We still want a binding redirect generated for it in 4.0, but not for 4.5.  
2013-06-13

---

I followed the exact same steps above, but there's no binding redirect added to the Console Application. It's only added to the __Portable Library project__. Is that the bug?  
2013-06-13

---

The binding redirects added to the Portable Library project seems to come from the Microsoft.Bcl package itself (from the content folder's app.config.transform file). this looks like a non-bug.
2013-06-13

  
I'm chasing up the repro with Eric St. John. He walked through the code and figured out where it was broken.

It's the not the app.config.tranform, notice how the net45 content is empty, and hence no transforms. We also marked our transforms with a special marker that indicates that we added the redirects . The binding redirects we were seeing were not coming from us.  
2013-06-13

---

Are you seeing the binding redirects added to the Console Application or the Portable Library? I don't see binding redirect added to Console Application, only the Portable Library.  
2013-06-13

---

Yes I'm talking about the ConsoleApplication. The binding redirects in the portable library project are expected, and do not affect runtime behavior (as the app.config is ignored and not copied to the app project), and hence can't cause an application to crash.

I've found another repro (NuGet has really weird logic around when it decides to add binding redirects so it was hard to find a repro).

The repro is instead of using the Microsoft.Bcl package, install the Microsoft.Net.Http, 2.2.3-beta package. Make sure you are targeting __4.5__ from the ConsoleApplication and the exact platforms that I called out above for portable.  
2013-06-13

---

Also, the ConsoleApplication must be referencing the portable project before installing the package.  
2013-06-13

---

OK now I can repro  
2013-06-14

---

OK, I've got a fix now. It no longer adds the binding redirect for System.Runtime.dll, but still adds one for System.Net.Http.Primitives. I guess it's expected, right? Please confirm.

```
<assemblyBinding xmlns="urn:schemas-microsoft-com:asm.v1">
<dependentAssembly>
<assemblyIdentity name="System.Net.Http.Primitives" publicKeyToken="b03f5f7f11d50a3a" culture="neutral" />
<bindingRedirect oldVersion="0.0.0.0-4.2.3.0" newVersion="4.2.3.0" />
</dependentAssembly>
</assemblyBinding>
```  
2013-06-14

---


Yes that's correct. System.Net.Http.Primitives does not exist in the framework.  
2013-06-14

---

Fixed in changeset b8d515f6341193b970d2a9d837e580e762d2eb71  
2013-06-19

---

i get the same issue with my test project still, runtime being added... if i comment this out the tests run fine... if not i get exceptions thrown from json.net  
2013-08-09

---

(or i can change the version up to 4.0.0.0 or something and it works)  
2013-08-09

---

2013-06-13

---

OK now I can repro  
2013-06-14

---

```
